newsitem.title: USA: Analysts turn bullish on Ford after executive update.
newsitem.headline: Analysts turn bullish on Ford after executive update.

text.p: Impressed by cost-cutting progress at Ford Motor Co., auto industry analysts are turning more bullish on the company, convinced it will continue to outpace its Big Three rivals in rewarding shareholders.

Two analysts this week raised their second-quarter and full-year 1997 earnings-per-share estimates on Ford after two days of upbeat meetings with senior executives at the automaker's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich.
"I think from a fundamentals standpoint, of the Big Three, Ford is in the best shape," Michael Ward, an analyst with PaineWebber, said.
Ward said he now expects Ford to earn $1.82 a share in the second quarter, up from $1.60 a share a year earlier. He also predicts the company will earn $5 a share in all of 1997, and $5.50 next year.
The stock price of the nation's No. 2 automaker has already outperformed that of General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. since the beginning of the year.
Ford's stock, which was trading at $37.375 Friday, is up more than 15 percent this year, compared with approximate gains for GM and Chrysler of 1 percent and 3 percent, respectively.

Analysts now think Ford's stock could push beyond $40 a share. They believe the company is poised to reap more rewards from strong -- and profitable -- light-truck sales, a conservative production schedule, sound dealer inventories and relative peace with the United Auto Workers union.
Analysts are also optimistic about a share repurchase from Ford's board of directors sometime in the second half of 1997.

"Opportunities for a share repurchase programme are arguably much stronger now than at any point since the cycle began," Salomon Brothers analyst Jack Kirnan said in a research report. Kirnan noted Ford is expected to have net cash of at least $10 billion by the end of June.
Ward predicted Ford could buy back about $1 billion worth of stock and still have enough cash to repurchase more shares in 1998 and modestly boost its dividend in both years.

Ford is the only member of the Big Three that did not announce a buyback programme for this year. GM has set a $2.5 billion buyback programme this year. Chrysler is about half-way through a $2 billion repurchase programme this year.

As a result of sweeping cost-cutting measures around the company's worldwide operations, some analysts believe Ford will be able to slash 1997 actual costs by $2 billion from its total costs of $110 billion for all of 1996.
That would significantly exceed Ford's original goal of trimming actual costs by $1 billion in 1997.
"The auto industry has set out big goals in the past but what we've never seen is actual costs come down in a year," Ward said. "That's a very, very strong statement from any auto manufacturer."

Not everyone is convinced of a rosy future for Ford, however. On Thursday Credit Suisse First Boston analyst Nicholas Colas cut his rating on the automaker to a hold from a buy. Colas could not be reached for comment.
Michael Robinet, managing director of CSM Forecasting, an industry consultant in Farmington Hills, Mich., said Ford continues to lose ground in the passenger car segment.
He also believes Ford is too optimistic about the potential for future light truck sales, which he said are already showing signs of slowing.
"On trucks they still rule the roost," he said. "But the jury is still out on continued growth in the future."
